content:
Hi all
I am v concerned about validators feeling entitled to extract MEV. It makes it hard to resolve the MEV issue down the line without fork risk. Here is a discussion of this inc links to a solution- the Alex content consensus protocol. Fair/encrypted variants to come.
https://pmcgoohan.medium.com/mev-do-this-beb2754bca63

author: izz.y
content: I have a similar fear, and I've also been tossing around an idea in my head that EV capture on POS will create strong economic incentives for POS (semi-)centralized staking "megapools". I've written about it here: https://twitter.com/IsdrsP/status/1389160909470412800 (full read here https://hackmd.io/@Izzy-/Eth2VevStaking). I wonder what thoughts other have as well. In my opinion the sooner these kinds of negative externalities are solved the better it will be for the network.

author: sky.cactus
content: IMO it is largely up to protocols built on top of Ethereum to solve them, not the base layer.

author: sky.cactus
content: As long as the protocols don't care enough to solve them, these opportunities will exist.

author: sky.cactus
content: Introducing a huge amount of complexity or worse UX for *everything* into the base layer (which is what would be required) because some protocols introduce value extraction opportunities isn't the right solution.

author: izz.y
content: This is kind of an ideological battleground type question that I side-stepped in my analysis because I think it's not something that will change in the immediate future (or potentially ever). I also acknowledge that potentially solving it at the protocol layer means that you just create an arb opportunity from a cross-protocol perspective. So instead, I assume the status quo and I focused on where I think the economic benefits of "EV Farming" may lead the network and the effects it'll have on the network of stakers and validators. I think this problem is a lot more immediate than we think, and I believe that once a trajectory towards centralized/permissioned staking pools is set it's going to be very difficult to change course.

author: pmcgoohan
content: I disagree that it is an ideological battle. Mainnet suffers from low data integrity and high data corruption in terms of tx ordering. Worse than any transactional system I can think of. It's a purely technical problem. The ideologues are those that think we should use inappropriate free market solutions to address a system vulnerability which maximize data corruption. You can't fix this stuff in 1 block in the app layer on mainnet, and L2 will also need a content layer to avoid the same issues.

content:
What problem arises from payment for execution flow? I'm not understanding. How does this lead to centralization? I see no rational basis for this theory. And what's the proposed solution assuming this theory is even correct? Payment for order flow is the entire basis of transaction ordering in a public blockchain. [Gwei bid, MEV, etc] - I find this discussion a bit silly considering that.

In the above referenced paper, the suggestion is to: "Enforce socialized reward distribution by requiring that validators specify, as the priority fee coinbase address, a smart-contract address that would appropriately redistribute EV rewards across the pool. Failure to do so by a node operator would result in penalizing of their collateral and/or stake (e.g. at withdrawal)." - which uh, sounds pretty centralized and anticompetitive to me? author: izz.y
content: This is what centralized staking pools will do anyway. The proposal is to come up with a way to do it in a decentralized and trustless manner so that decentralized staking pools can actually compete (well, come close to) in terms of rewards they would offer staking participants and node operators.

author: jgm
content: Surely if such a system is better than not having it, then decentralized staking pools will use it anyway.  Why the requirement to force it, if it's already the best solution?

author: izz.y
content: this is an on-protocol solution and not a through-the-protocol solution, the problem it's trying to solve is that basically decentralized staking pools and solo validators will basically be economically detrimental to run/operate in compared to the returns one would get via centralized participation

author: izz.y
content: I'm not suggesting to force it. I'm suggesting that decentralized protocols should implement it so that it's available sooner rather than later, because implementing it "later" may be too late.

author: izz.y
content: Realistically you can't compete on cost against centralized providers, so what you have to do is bring cost as close as possible and then try to compete on service offering/timing.

author: izz.y
content: It's doubly hard to compete on timing because centralized implementations can generally be executed quicker because they're simpler to design, so it' s important to recognize the problem now and start designing for it.

author: izz.y
content: It's a call to action, not an EIP.

author: jgm
content:
A server running a single validator will always be more costly than a server running multiple validators, as there is (at least partially) a flat cost to running a validator, that's true today.  Some people are willing to pay that price to be solo validators, though, as they value their own technical knowledge or ability, or the decentralization of the network, and that offsets the additional money they may have been making.

It may be that as the delta changes some people move from decentralized to centralized, but if the absolute returns also increases then perhaps people will move the other way as well.

author: izz.y
content: In principle I agree. But what I'm trying to argue is that the absolute return will not increase in favor of solo validation (doesnt even have to be just 1 validator, it can be multiple). The bigger the pool, the larger the capture of consistent EV, the more funds it will be drawn, in a loop. This is because the capture of EV is disproportionately more rewarding than capturing vanilla staking rewards. Therefore to maximize rewards you want to maximize EV capture, which means maximizing probability of block proposals.

author: izz.y
content: In the "vanilla staking" environment there's kind of an equilibrium between the attestation rewards and the block proposal rewards, but this is going to be thrown off with EV capture (because EV rewards are not based on the staking mechanism, but based on the tx volume and tx makeup of the bundle included).

author: jgm
content:
As for the issue of solo validators not being trusted by EV searchers: I suspect that this itself will be decentralized, in that one or more "validators" will actually be decentralized pools of validators.  The individual pools may or may not have rules for how they distribute rewards, and no doubt various pools with different options will be available, but the general idea is that there will be a full range of choices from solo validators through federation through large-scale centralized services.  And they will play each other in the market, with perhaps the solo validator asking lower fees in return for the potential higher risk.

There are multiple spectrums on which this can play, and I'm sure it will.  But I don't see it being a "fall to centralization" style issue, to be honest.

author: izz.y
content:
> I suspect that this itself will be decentralized, in that one or more "validators" will actually be decentralized pools of validators. 
Yeah that's basically what I'm arguing for, but I'm saying that these decentralized pools will need to be *big* to prevent the "fall to centralization". Probably even that taken *en bloc* they should constitute the majority of the network.

author: jgm
content:
Back to market economics: I think that they can be of all sizes, because the smaller ones can offer cheaper prices to offset potential costs to the searchers.

So I don't think there is a specific size requirement necessary for success.

author: izz.y
content: Smaller ones cannot offer cheaper prices because their marginal cost for each additional validator is higher than for centralized services.

author: izz.y
content: Obviously currently centralized staking services are not offering competitive commissions, but it's purely because they don't currently need to. They are already capturing almost the majority of the market (ok I misspoke, purely centralized is ~30% from what we can tell, but this is without coinbase and another 10-15% which is "semi-centralized") without having to do so. Eventually smaller operators can/will be priced out and they will be a very small minority of stake share mostly run by people who are doing it almost altruistically (which is great, it's just not going to mean much for the network as a whole).

author: sky.cactus
content: FWIW, there are solutions to MEV extraction via searchers that make it so searchers don't need to trust the block producers.  This would make it so anyone could participate in MEV block production anonymously.  At that point, the only reason you would pool would be for fee smoothing.

author: izz.y
content: If these solutions don't drastically increase the marginal cost of operating a validator by a lot I agree, but I had understood that currently proposed solutions require specialized hardware or computional resources that are expensive to "rent" for the "privacy" computations.

author: izz.y
content: Happy to do some reading if you can point me to some resources! OTOH if you are running only a few validators and you have a relatively low probability of proposing blocks, I feel like it's almost potentially more beneficial to run your "own" EV Searcher somehow (or rent the computation power to do so), provided you have the liquidity required to be doing the actual sandwiching etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: You can shift those costs back to the searchers with sufficient engineering.

author: sky.cactus
content: Basically the searcher makes a bonded promise to the validator, and if the searcher lies they are slashed and the validator is rewarded.

author: sky.cactus
content: This way the validator only needs to execute on bundle (the best one they receive based on claims by the searcher) and if the bundle doesn't pay the validator what was claimed then the validator gets compensated for their lost opportunity.

author: izz.y
content: Sounds interesting. Definitely interested in reading more about this.
